section-block.rac_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Book: Baby on Board: How Animals Carry Their Young

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Marianne Berkes and illustrated by Cathy Morrison
section-block.rac_book_summary: Without strollers or baby backpacks, animal parents have to find creative ways to carry their babies! This book shows the many clever ways that animals carry their babies and keep them safe.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about where animals live. Explain that they will use words like in, on, and under to talk about where someone or something is located.
Invite children to sing to the tune of “Wheels on the Bus” as they mimic animal sounds. “The cows in the barn go, moo, moo, moo....” Build excitement for learning about animals.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a book called Baby on Board by Marianne Berkes.
Scout loves reading informational books like this one. Informational books tell about the real world.
I have a special question that I want you to think about as we read. We’ll talk about it after we’ve read the book. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do some animal parents carry their babies?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at the baby sloth’s long claws! The baby sloth clings with its long claws onto its mama.
Baby opossums are called joeys!
Do you think it’s easy or hard for the mother opossum to haul her babies? Why?
How does the mother chimp carry her baby? What does that remind you of?
Look at the picture. Why were the baby alligators calling their mother? Where does the mother alligator carry her babies?
The father penguin holds the egg on his feet. The word on is called a preposition. Prepositions help us tell where things are.
section.rac_body-text: Model under, behind, and next to for children.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s see what other prepositions we can find today.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Let’s talk about the guiding question:
How do some animal parents carry their babies?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Alligator mothers carry their babies in their mouths.
Opossum mothers carry their babies on their backs.
Chimps carry their babies in their arms.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about animal families as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does the alligator carry her babies in her mouth or her hands?
The alligator carries her babies in her m________ (mouth).
The alligator carries her babies in her mouth.
In what other ways do animal parents carry their babies?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Illustrations in picture books engage and provide meaning of an informational text for young children. Help children enjoy a text and develop their understanding by encouraging them to look closely at illustrations.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Focus Attention
section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that when they focus their attention, they must keep looking at, listening to, or thinking about something, even if they want to be doing something else. Explain that, during story time, it is important to stay focused on the book so that they do not miss important information. Asking questions can help with staying focused.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we’re going to show curiosity and ask questions as we revisit the book Baby on Board written by Marianne Berkes.
Clifford loves to ask questions to help him stay focused. He is curious to learn about animals!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we reread the book, try to stay focused on it the whole time that I am reading. One way to stay focused when you are reading is to ask questions. When you ask questions, you show curiosity about the book.**
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The mother kangaroo keeps her joey, which is the name for her baby, in a pouch. Why do you think she does that?
This mother transports her pup on her chest. Human parents often transport their children, too! They can transport their children in a car, on a bus, or on a bike!
Why doesn’t the sea otter transport her pup in a car?
The baby manatee swims close to its mother. Where does the baby like the most?
The mother spider keeps track of her hundreds of spiderlings! What do we learn about spiders?
How does a mama anteater carry a baby anteater?
What questions do you have about anteaters? When you ask a question, you can start with the word why. (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Sit in a circle with the children. Ask the child to your left a question (for example, “What is your favorite activity?”). After the child answers your question, have him or her show curiosity by asking a question to the next child in the circle. Continue going around the circle until all children have had a chance to ask and answer at least one question. (MB)
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about how their favorite animal takes care of its babies.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Focusing one’s attention is a basic executive function skill that children need to develop in order to begin learning. Children must work through several steps to successfully pay attention: 1) be alert, 2) select what to pay attention to and sustain that attention even with outside distractions, and 3) if distracted, shift focus back to task. (Rosen, 2019)

section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that when they think about how one thing is like another, they are making a connection.
Have children form a circle and play telephone using an animal name. Continue playing additional rounds with different children starting and using new words.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Baby on Board by Marianne Berkes.
This book is an informational book because it tells true things about animal families. Scout loves reading about animal families!
The guiding question that I want you to think about as we read is:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How are animal parents and human parents the same?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How are the human parents carrying the baby?
The mother manatee remains close to her calf. Why do you think she does this? Do human parents remain close to their babies? Why do you think they do? (MB)
The mother chimp prepares a nest for her babies every day.
Why do you think she makes her nests in trees?
The mother alligator helps her babies stay safe by carrying them to safety in her jaws. How do your parents help you stay safe?
Look at the picture. The mother lion hides her cubs. Why are these bushes a good place to hide lion cubs?
Did you think about the guiding question while we read? Let’s talk about it now. Talk to your partner about this question: How are animal parents and human parents the same?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They are the same because they both carry their babies.
They are the same because they both keep their babies safe.
They are the same because they both feed their babies.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about how an animal takes care of its young, inviting children to suggest prepositions.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do human parents carry their babies?
How are human parents and animal parents different?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Pretend play helps young children develop empathy and build self-esteem. Engaging in pretend play with other children helps them learn how to take turns.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion about the animal families they learned about this week. Which animal was their favorite and why?
Use the PreK On My Way™ theme music to inspire children to dance like an animal.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we’re going to read our Big Chart, The Chicks Say, “Pio, Pio, Pio.” It is a poster that has a song about little chicks and their mother.
Scout loves singing songs, especially songs about animals!
The song “The Chicks Say, ‘Pio, Pio, Pio’” and the book Baby on Board are both about animal families. Let’s see if we can find any connections between the two!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Baby on Board book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As I read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can come point to the mother? Who can come point to the chicks? What do the chicks say?
The chicks’ mother is called a hen. What food does the hen give to her chicks? Can you remember from the song?
When we read Baby on Board, what did you learn about the food a mother anteater gives her baby?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show pages 24–25 of Baby on Board.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The hen offers her chicks shelter. Where are the chicks?
The chicks are very hungry. What will their mother do?

section.rac_body-text: Invite a child to think of an animal and give clues about how the animal cares for its babies. Clues can be spoken, acted out, or drawn. Challenge other children to guess the animal. Have children take turns giving clues and guessing the animal.
Provide a writing prompt about animal families and give guidance as children draw and write.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Giving children sufficient time to respond after you ask a question is always important, but it is especially important for multilingual learners. It takes time for them to process the question, retrieve the words they know, and formulate and express a response. When you pose a question to a multilingual learner, allow them the time they need to respond.

section-block.rac_body-text: Divide the class into two groups. One group calls out the name of an animal family they learned about this week. The other group must pretend to be a family of that kind of animal, feeding and caring for its babies.
Introduce two new words that we’ll use today.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Baby on Board.
This book is an informational text. That means that it gives true information about a topic. Scout loves reading informational texts!
This week we read and learned about how different animals care for their babies. As we read this book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: If you could be any animal in this book, which would you be? Why?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at how the mother kangaroo hops with her baby in her pouch! Can you show me how you would hop if you were a kangaroo?
It must be hard work for the opossum mother to haul her babies around! Can you show me how you would haul something from one place to another?
Why does the loon baby ride on his father’s back? What sound do you think loons make?
Baby spiders climb onto their mother’s back as soon as they are hatched.
Pretend that you are a baby spider hatching from your egg.
The penguin father keeps the egg warm by balancing it on his feet.
Show me how you can balance a ball on your feet.
Something that has gone astray means it has gone the wrong way. How does the lion mother pick up a cub that has gone astray? Does she look happy to you? Why?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to talk about the guiding question with a partner:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: If you could be any animal in this book, which would you be? Why?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I would be a baby kangaroo so I could live in a pouch.
I would be a baby chimp so I could sleep in a tree.
I would be a baby opossum so I could ride on my mother’s back.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about animal families and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Would you like to sleep in a tree?
I would like to sleep in a tr________ (tree).
I would like to sleep in a tree.
What would you not like about being a chimp?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Did you know that the onomatopoeia used to describe animal sounds varies across languages? A pig, for example, goes oink oink in English, boo boo in Japanese, and chrum chrum in Polish! If you have multilingual learners in your classroom, invite them to share the sound their favorite animal makes in their home language.
